results.title: Running water: erosion & deposition
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Earth revealed”.
What do rivers do? The power or velocity of river flow is responsible for some of the most unique sculpting of landforms on the planet. Running water transports sediments and deposits it at river mouths and deltas as well as abrasively smoothing and wearing away bedrock on its course. Geologists study the ways rivers flow and meander in order to solve problems of flooding and silting as well as assiting engineers in the construction of dams and dykes in order to improve flow of water.

results.title: Bette Davis' eyes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
What makes a star? Clips from a host of films look at the legendary stars - Sarah Bernhardt, Shirley Temple, Joan Crawford, Errol Flynn and Bette Davis. This program is episode seven in the ten part documentary, “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Being True Blue
results.creator_credit: Kay Donovan, Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This documentary explores what it means to be an Australian citizen and just what a new citizen is welcome to. In interviews with historians, social planners and ordinary people, ‘Being True Blue’ looks behind the facade of the national anthem, the sports hero, the bushman and the other cheap barometers of identity.

results.title: Poor Man's Cinema
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
It’s what countries like Australia produce - documentaries! John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the renaissance of the ‘60s as well as the Hollywood wartime documentaries, and their effect on the evolution of cinema.

results.title: Days of Stargazey Pie
results.creator_credit: Margaret Haselgrove, Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Cornish descendants, a tourist guide and a historian talk about the contribution that the Cornish miners made to the development of the South Australian copper mines at Burra and Moonta. We also look at some of their traditions which have been handed down from generation to generation in this ‘Little Cornwall”

results.title: Mass wasting
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Mass wasting is the continual chain of processes that move earth, rocks and debris from the top of landmasses to the bottom. Tectonic activity and gravity assist the process which can result in gradual creeps and slumps to more damaging landslides and avalanches. The effects of mass wasting are important to geologists as they assist engineers in the design and construction of structures on potentially unstable landforms.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Earth revealed”.

results.title: Weathering & soils
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Weathering of the earth’s surface is important to geologists as they examine the impact of this process. There are two types: mechanical and chemical weathering. Mechanical weathering involves the disintegration and break-up of fragments of rock at the earth’s surface naturally. The composition of the rock doesn’t change at all. In chemical weathering, water and air decompose the rock and change its composition such as iron ore can become oxidised into rust in the presence of water. Acid raid formation is affected by the chemical weathering of the earth’s surface as is soil composition and productivity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television

results.title: Intrusive igneous rocks
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Unveils the rock-forming processing of magmas that do not reach earth’s surface but solidfy. Igneous rocks are classed as plutonic and volcanic; the differences are determined by the way the magma cools and hardens. Not all minerals are formed at the same time, and the crystalisation process results in different minerals being formed. Igneous activity is related also to Plate tectonics, while the moon is largely made up of igneous material rarely found on the surface of the earth.

results.title: Volcanism
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Volcanoes are often found where the continental plates converge or diverge, or in designated “hot spots” in the middle of plates such as can be found in the Hawaiian region. A handful of special volcanoes formed along rift zones, can also be found. The study of volcanoes and their activities, casts new light on the internal structure of the earth and their impact on other phenomena such as the weather.

results.title: Minerals: the materials of earth
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Minerals are the raw materials of rocks. Although there are over 2,000 minerals, only about 200 of them are common. Quartz, diamonds, graphite, are just some of the basic minerals found in the earth’s crust. It is the way in which the atoms are arranged that determine the composition and structure of minerals, as well as their physical properties. It is the correlation between these elements which geologists analyse.
